content.value_statement: Creating publication-quality statistical visualizations requires significant boilerplate code and design decisions. This skill provides optimized access to seaborn library functions for generating box plots, violin plots, heatmaps, and pair plots with attractive defaults and pandas integration.
actual_capabilities: Generate box plots for comparing distributions across categories with automatic styling
Create violin plots that combine box plot and kernel density estimation visualizations
Build heatmaps for visualizing matrix data with annotated color scales
Produce pair plots for exploring relationships between multiple variables
Apply seaborn theme settings for consistent, publication-quality figure styling
Integrate seamlessly with pandas DataFrames for direct data visualization workflows
limitations: Does not provide interactive visualizations (use plotly skill for interactive plots)
Requires matplotlib and pandas dependencies to be installed in the environment
Does not support 3D visualization (use mayavi or plotly for 3D plots)
Limited to 2D statistical visualization techniques included in seaborn library

use_cases.target_user: Machine learning engineers and data scientists preparing feature engineering

use_cases.title: Generate Publication-Quality Figures

prompt_templates.title: Basic Box Plot
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the seaborn skill to create a box plot comparing values across a categorical variable. Use the sample_data DataFrame with 'category' as the x-axis and 'value' as the y-axis. Apply the seaborn default theme and add appropriate labels.

prompt_templates.title: Styled Violin Plot
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a violin plot with the seaborn skill showing the distribution of 'scores' by 'treatment_group' from experiment_data. Include the inner='box' option to show quartiles. Use a professional color palette and set figure size to 10x6.

prompt_templates.title: Correlation Heatmap
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a heatmap using seaborn to visualize the correlation matrix from features_df. Annotate cells with correlation values, use a diverging colormap centered at 0, and include a colorbar legend. Set the figure size appropriately for readability.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Variable Pair Plot
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a pair plot using seaborn for the columns ['sepal_length', 'sepal_width', 'petal_length', 'petal_width'] from iris_data. Color points by species, show scatter plots on lower triangle and distributions on diagonal, and use a subplot grid size of 12x12.
prompt_templates.scenario: Exploratory data analysis with multiple variables

output_examples.input: Create a box plot showing revenue by region using the sales_data DataFrame. Set region as x-axis and revenue as y-axis.
output_examples.output: A box plot figure with regions on the x-axis, revenue on the y-axis, showing median, quartiles, and outliers for each region. Clean styling with seaborn defaults applied.

output_examples.input: Generate a heatmap of the correlation matrix from customer_data with annotations showing the correlation coefficients.
output_examples.output: A square heatmap with cells colored by correlation strength (red-blue diverging palette), numeric annotations in each cell, and a colorbar legend showing the scale.

output_examples.input: Create a violin plot of response times by priority level from support_data, with box inside showing quartiles.
output_examples.output: A violin plot with priority levels on x-axis and response times on y-axis. Each violin shows the full distribution, with a box plot overlay displaying median and quartile lines.

best_practices: Use consistent figure sizes (set via matplotlib figure parameters) when creating multiple related visualizations for reports
Apply seaborn theme settings (sns.set_theme) once at the beginning of sessions for consistent styling across all generated figures
Choose appropriate color palettes (diverging for correlations, sequential for magnitudes) to accurately represent data relationships
anti_patterns: Avoid creating overly complex visualizations with too many categories (consider aggregating or filtering data first)
Do not use box plots for very small sample sizes where violin or strip plots would show the distribution better
Avoid overwhelming figures with excessive annotations; keep labels and titles clear and concise

faq.question: What is the difference between box plots and violin plots in seaborn?
faq.answer: Box plots show summary statistics (median, quartiles, outliers) as a box with whiskers. Violin plots show the full distribution shape using kernel density estimation, making them better for understanding data distribution beyond summary statistics.

faq.question: Can I use seaborn with data stored in pandas DataFrames?
faq.answer: Yes, seaborn is designed for pandas integration. Pass the DataFrame to functions along with column names for x, y, and hue parameters. Seaborn automatically handles data access from the DataFrame.

faq.question: How do I save seaborn figures for publication?
faq.answer: Use matplotlib's savefig function after creating your seaborn plot. Set dpi=300 for high resolution, specify the format (PNG, PDF, SVG) in the filename, and adjust figure size before saving.

faq.question: What color palettes are available in seaborn?
faq.answer: Seaborn provides named palettes like 'deep', 'muted', 'pastel', 'bright', 'dark', and 'colorblind'. You can also create custom palettes using sns.color_palette() with specific colors or using built-in palettes like 'husl' or 'cubehelix'.

faq.question: How do I customize seaborn figure styling globally?
faq.answer: Use sns.set_theme() or sns.set_style(), sns.set_context(), and sns.set_palette() to control the theme, plotting context (paper, talk, poster), and color palette across all figures in your session.

faq.question: Can I combine matplotlib and seaborn in the same figure?
faq.answer: Yes, seaborn returns matplotlib axes objects that can be customized with matplotlib functions. You can add annotations, modify axis limits, or layer additional plots using standard matplotlib commands on seaborn-generated axes.
